awd_titl_txt: Chiral Plasmonics at the Single Nanoparticle and Single Molecule Level
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Professor Stephen Link of William March Rice University to study chiral plasmonics on the single nanoparticle and potentially single molecule scale. Chiral objects cannot be overlaid with their mirror image. An everyday example of this is human hands- a right handed glove doesn't fit on the left hand.  Therefore, the chirality of an object is sometimes termed its handedness. Many important molecules are chiral, including drugs, proteins, and DNA.  In the case of pharmaceuticals, the chirality of the drug is absolutely essential to its function.  Molecular chirality is measured by circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy. Stephan Link, at Rice University, is developing novel highly sensitive methods to measure the chirality of single molecules.  The applications of this work include biomedical research, the pharmaceutical industry, and chemical synthesis and catalysis. The excitement about scientific research and discovery in nanotechnology is communicated through outreach activities such as Rice University's Civic Scientist Program to K-12 students to inspire them to pursue careers in science-related fields.   

The objectives of this proposal are to be accomplished using unique spectroscopic methods capable of recording CD spectra of single plasmonic nanoparticles and super-resolution imaging single molecules, in combination with electron microscopy and electromagnetic simulations. The relationship between CD signal enhancement and nanostructure composition and morphology (size, shape, interparticle coupling) and the intrinsically linked plasmon modes (bright, dark) is possible with the proposed studies. This information cannot be obtained in ensemble measurements, especially for strongly coupled nanoparticles prepared by chemical synthesis. The outcomes of these studies are expected have wide scientific impact in areas ranging from the development of chiral sensing platforms,  and of chiral catalysts to the basis of plasmon-exciton coupling. Concepts from multiple disciplines are included in this research, forming a platform for a broad educational program specifically designed for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. Exciting vignettes related to scientific research and discovery in nanotechnology are to be communicated to K-12 students through outreach activities, such as Rice University's Civic Scientist Program,  to expose these students to the potential for creative advancement via careers in STEM-related fields.

por.por_cntn:
Nanoparticle-based materials are becoming increasingly popular in multiple areas of current technology. This NSF award, titled “Chrial Plasmonics at the Single Particle and Single Molecule Level,” was funded to investigate the optical properties of chiral nanoparticle assemblies with and without chiral molecules adsorbed to their surfaces. The results of this research point toward the possibility of sensing chirality and hence molecular structure at ultralow concentrations by taking advantage of the amplification from the plasmon resonance, the coherent oscillation of conduction band electrons in metal nanoparticles.

 

Chiral objects are not superimposable with their mirror image, or enantiomer. Chirality is commonly illustrated using hands, and thus the chirality of an object is termed its handedness. Chirality is measured by circular dichroism spectroscopy. A major drawback of circular dichroism spectroscopy is the limited sensitivity because of the much smaller length scales of molecular chiral elements compared to the helical pitch of circularly polarized light. Metallic nanostructures have been proposed to enhance the circular dichroism of chiral molecules. However, the underlying mechanistic factors were not well understood at the start of this project. The goal therefore was to determine how plasmons can be used to amplify the circular dichrosim of chiral molecules.

 

To accomplish this goal we first developed single particle circular differential scattering spectroscopy to measure the chirality of individual chiral nanoparticle assemblies with high confidence. Correlated electron microscopy and electromagnetic modeling aided in the interpretation of the spectroscopic signal. A major outcome of this instrument development was the ability to measure individual enantiomers even for a racemic mixture of equal populations of left- and right-handed enantiomers, which would not result in chiroptical activity in ensemble measurements.

 

With the help of this new tool we disentangled the origin of the ensemble circular dichroism from a mixture of nanoparticles and proteins. We found that the observed chirality originates from both chiral nanoparticles assemblies as well as from chiral proteins transferring their chirality to the plasmon resonance. For the latter case in this specific system, the proteins had to be located in between two neighboring nanoparticles to take advantage of signal amplification by the electromagnetic hotspots present in the gaps. We furthermore determined that only a few proteins (~1-5) could be present in the gaps, opening the possibility of performing single molecule circular dichroism spectroscopy in the future.

 

This NSF award supported research activities for 2 graduate students, 2 undergraduates, and 3 postdoctoral researchers and yielded 10 publications. Those involved have had the opportunity to learn sophisticated single particle/molecule techniques, data analysis, and electromagnetic modeling as well as carry out collaborative research, present their results at local and national conferences, and publish in peer-reviewed journals. The results of these studies are significant because they have the potential for developing highly sensitive methods to measure the circular dichroism spectra of chiral molecules in ultralow quantities.
